title: Will US print book sales in 2021 exceed those in 2020?
preds:
Reasoning from https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1314926 looks robust in the face of  https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/88068-print-unit-sales-rose-9-7-in-late-november.html
https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/88191-print-book-sales-dip-during-the-week-before-christmas.html
re. @jayb 's link: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/87967-print-units-rose-11-7-in-mid-november.html it seems almost certain to be above at this point

Sales up ~11% for the first 2 weeks of Nov yoy, and net substantially up for the rest of the year before that. It's hard to see how this year could end up lower than last. Book sellers would need to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory.

Revising slightly upward based on the latest data:
"unit sales of print books rose 17.3% in the week ended Nov. 6, 2021, over the comparable week in 2020"
Previous 2021 data summarized here:
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1351722
Data from here: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/search/index.html?q=print+book+sales+2021&submit.x=0&submit.y=0&sortByDate=on

Maintaining forecast despite possible (reported) supply-chain issues, although: “Bigger retailers are going to probably be prioritized...”: https://www.marketplace.org/2021/11/10/supply-chain-snags-hit-books/
From 91% to 93%. See comment by @belikewater https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1351722
It's looking like Delta might have helped sustain the gains. I'm going to just trust the comments of others and not do my own homework at this point due to lack of time.

Yoy, print book sales were:
* up 18.5% in the first half of the year
* down 2% in Q3
* up in October:
  * 2% in week ending Oct 9
  * 2.7% in week ending Oct 16
  * 7% in week ending Oct 23
  * 12% in week ending Oct 30
So it looks likely that to date, print book sales are likely net substantially up for 2021 so far, with only 2 months to go. There do appear to be some supply chain issues, but there doesn't yet appear to be any shortage of print books.

Seems extremely likely as 2021 was already ahead of 2020 and lead continues to rise in October according to https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/87768-unit-sales-of-print-books-rose-7-in-mid-october.html, https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/87633-fiction-drove-small-gain-in-print-book-sales-last-week.html
as @jayb has pointed out sales are continually up, and as @DNK89 pointed out, there would need to be a substantial decline in Q4 to fall below 2020, so I'm coming up 10%
WONDER HOW MANY PRINT RUNS ARE WAITING ON A SHIP TO GET UNLOADED IN PORT?
Slight reduction in probability based on supply chain issues. Will need to follow this closely.
Latest 3 book press releases fro NPD all look to indicate lower sales and if there are supply chain interruptions it will push people back to ebooks.
moderating based on supply chain concerns

The only slightly worrying sign i see is the supply chain issues
https://edition.cnn.com/2021/09/21/business/book-publishing-delays-supply-chain-cec/index.html At this point Sales in Q4 have to decline by more than 22%, if 2021 has to end below 2020 levels
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1UEYy0btpv3Yqeg1S8BpTvAnCs1KYTq4s/edit#gid=1169327932

Market seems bullish for Yes and I feel like I'm missing some key piece of evidence everyone else has access to but me. Anyone care to fill me in? What I've read is it seems like it might still be a great year for sales but still fall short of last year due to sliding back to normal.
Shifting up now that I'm catching up on some overdue forecasts.  11.8% ahead at  Sept 11 feels tough to overcome
Updating based on link in comment by @jayb https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1340027
Looks like Q3 will come in around 3% decline from 2020. Ready to call it.
Some evidence that the growth of sales may be better than expected. Tweaking up.
Coming down slightly on the chance that supply chain issues or an economic downturn upend the numbers: https://qz.com/2059755/book-publishers-warn-of-supply-chain-delays-for-2021-holidays/

Updating previous forecast: The following appears to show a fairly robust 11.8% total print unit sales advantage y-t-d through 9/11/21 vs. the same period in 2020:  https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/87407-print-unit-sales-dipped-in-early-september.html The fourth quarter is usually the largest for book sales. Increasing forecast for now

Waiting for a third quarter '21 sales summary report (vs. 2020 sales) before further adjusting this forecast. 2021 sales had a large first half lead over the same 2020 period (+18.5%), but several recent weekly sales reports have underperformed vs. 2020. E.g.: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/87372-unit-sales-slipped-1-2-last-week.html https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/87325-adult-fiction-was-the-lone-bright-spot-last-week.htm https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/87305-print-unit-sales-fell-2-3-at-end-of-august.html

No change; also haven't been following this question very closely.
https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/87347-book-publishing-s-rousing-first-half-of-2021.html

I still dissent from the crowd, but will opt for a "yes leaning tossup" as a defensive tactic since those of us that are vehement about a "yes" resolution are much louder than my own grumbling solar plexus.
No, the rise was an anomaly due to so many readers being home during the quarantine.
Probability of second half sales less than $306M given recent monthly averages is ≈ 0.16.
Going down slightly, but I still think that the implied decline would be too brutal.

As stated previously (I'm sure) the first half has been strong. As for the remainder of the year, I just ask how fickle are people and how long do good habits last? "
Unit sales throughout the first half of 2021 have shown continuous weekly increases compared to 2020, but sales gains have become smaller. In the first quarter, sales of print books were up 29% over the first quarter of 2020, a margin that has shrunk in the second quarter to about 8%. Some publishers have expressed concern over how the balance of 2021 will play out, as reading and book buying face more competition from forms of entertainment that were unavailable during Covid lockdowns. Others are betting that the rise in reading will remain for some period of time. There are still six months left to see who is right.
" https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86863-print-book-sales-soar-in-year-s-first-half.html Here is a thought. First half 2021 outpaced first half 2020... Well, Q1 is easy, there was no lockdown bump. Q2 was the beginning of lockdowns and I'm not convinced book buying was top of mind while we were obsessing over masks and WFH. The real test I imagine will be Q3 and Q4 which is likely where buying really ramped up. By then, it'll likely be too late for us to course correct.

I'm late to the party here but it looks like we're in August and 2021 sales are quite a bit higher than 2020 YTD sales were. So in order to see 2021 be lower than 2020 we'd have to see a significant slowdown and it looks like the slowdown is pretty gradual. https://publishingperspectives.com/2021/08/npd-sees-the-us-print-market-up-in-july-momentum-slowing/ Additionally many of the drivers (corona virus, political unrest, social justice issues) that made 2020 an outlier are still a factor this year.

I would presume that last year was an anomaly with people 1) stuck at home, 2) not commuting 3) not going on vacation... and 4) not consistent about good habits.
Wouldn't we imagine things getting somewhat back to normal? How's your sourdough starter doing these days?
https://www.statista.com/statistics/422595/print-book-sales-usa/
Increasing probability based on remark made by @Iamlegend745 https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1320211

Earlier on my forecasts were based on historical data and @jayb's hesitancy. Of late, forecasts have been based on rising trend in crowd median, lack of disproving of evidence, and periodical links provided by some users which appear to support the unexpected: 2021 will exceed 2020. But will it REALLY? Stay tuned. ***The close nature of the data and the initial view that 2020 may have been an outlier hard to beat is enough reason for me to stay away from certainty in 2021 exceeding 2020. I don't think we are at that stage.

https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/87122-print-book-sales-fell-8-last-week.html Gave me a half second of pause, but still not enough. Starting July 1st the decline had to be more than 14% per week from previous poster's comments. Rough estimate this number needs to be close to 20% decline moving forward each week to get us to be lower than 2020, I'll keep watching these to see if the declines pick up major steam.
Increasing the probability based on https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1319722 by @belikewater

With the pro's forecasting increased whole year sales in most scenarios it seems most likely to surpass 2020 even with the current slide. Check out @belikewater 's comments at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1319722

Some people seem to be reacting to news about the first half of the year because articles have recently come out about these gains. However, since then, sales have sometimes been falling a bit compared to last year. E.g.,
https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/87076-print-unit-sales-fell-1-7-last-week.html
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1310410
With projected declines in gains over the rest of the year, at least one analyst is arguing that 2021 will likely finish between 2% and 8% higher than 2020:
https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/financial-reporting/article/86935-print-book-sales-could-grow-by-2-this-year-or-by-8.html
So I think this forecast will end up being quite close. I do think the answer will be Yes, but I don't think it's a done deal.
I'm tempering a little to account for what appears to be increasing recession risk in Q4.

Half year print sales ticked past 386M (1), which leaves 365M sales in Q3 and Q4 in order to resolve as a yes - target is 751M+1. With Q1 sales of 208M, this means Q2 was 178M units, this is a whisper behind average pace I suggested would resolve this as a yes - 181M/Q (2).  I'm still anticipating a bump in Q4 numbers from holiday sales in the west, but the next couple months will be telling.  I'm tempering my optimism and will be checking in more often over the coming weeks.  1. https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86863-print-book-sales-soar-in-year-s-first-half.html
2. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1290983

https://www.statista.com/statistics/422595/print-book-sales-usa/
A considerable jump from 693.71 to 750.89 from 2019 to 2020 probably because of the pandemic, however other than 2008-2010 there has not been years with more than 750.
https://www.booksandpublishing.com.au/articles/2021/07/12/189433/us-print-book-sales-up-18-5-in-first-half-of-2021/
But booksales are up 18.5% in the first half of 2021 than the first half of 2020. What may be the probability distribution of book sales? Intuition says that it should be higly probable to be +-10% of the expected value.
I would go for 75%
Based on first half book sales were up about 18 per cent— I don’t expect a large drop from here.

Sales @ July 1, 2020: 326.5M (https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86863-print-book-sales-soar-in-year-s-first-half.html)
Sales @ July 1, 2021: 386.7M (https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86863-print-book-sales-soar-in-year-s-first-half.html)
Sales @ December 31, 2020: 751M (https://www.npd.com/news/press-releases/2021/after-a-slow-start--u-s--print-book-sales-rose-8-2-percent-in-2020--the-npd-group-says/)
Sales @ December 31, 2021: ?? *** https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/financial-reporting/article/86935-print-book-sales-could-grow-by-2-this-year-or-by-8.html
> If that is the case and sales run even with 2020 for the balance of the year, print unit sales will finish 2021 with an 8% gain over last year. If sales return closer to 2019 levels—which means a decline in sales in the last months of the year compared to 2020—sales would still finish the year ahead up 2% over 2020. The fastest growth rate, at 10% for the year, will be possible only if higher infection rates result in more lockdowns and stay-at-home orders, she said. Publishing “performed well with people at home,” McLean said in explaining why lockdowns may be good for the industry. She noted that she believes the 10% increase to be the least likely scenario, predicting that unit sales will finish the year with gains between 2% and 8%. Three scenarios in the picture: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/financial-reporting/article/86935-print-book-sales-could-grow-by-2-this-year-or-by-8.html, of which 2 see number of sales rise. *** US print book sales up 18.5% in first half of 2021 
https://www.booksandpublishing.com.au/articles/2021/07/12/189433/us-print-book-sales-up-18-5-in-first-half-of-2021/ *** https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/87007-declines-in-nonfiction-dropped-print-book-sales-last-week.html
> Last week was the third week in a row unit sales fell compared to 2020, but sales through late July were still 15.9% up over last year at outlets that report to NPD BookScan.  So the logic is that even if that 18.5% goes down by 2.6% every month, 2021 would still beat 2020. How sure am I of this logic? Not that much *** "The travel book subcategory had a severe decline last year, with units plunging 40.3% compared to 2019."
https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/85256-print-unit-sales-rose-8-2-in-2020.html ***

- Sales have increased 7 of the past 8 years according to https://www.statista.com/statistics/422595/print-book-sales-usa/
- US book sales up 18.5% in the first half of 2021 compared to the first half of 2020, according to https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86863-print-book-sales-soar-in-year-s-first-half.html. Based on https://publishingperspectives.com/2021/04/us-first-quarter-2021-print-book-sales-grew-29-percent-covid19/, seems like about 50k more books were sold during Q1 then Q2 was about equal
- As @Skyreichel pointed out, according to https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/financial-reporting/article/86935-print-book-sales-could-grow-by-2-this-year-or-by-8.html even if sales fall back to 2019 levels 2021 will still beat 2020 by 2%.
Making final decision, maybe too soon?  Thanks to https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1312389 by @Skyreichel and https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1306757 by @DNK89.

Super strong sales so far, but we are coming back down to earth - https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/financial-reporting/article/86935-print-book-sales-could-grow-by-2-this-year-or-by-8.html Most relevant quote from the article - if we return to 2019 sales we will finish up 2% over 2020 print sales. If we continue with 2020 numbers, we will be up 8%. Still not 100% convinced this will happen, but it's looking much more likely with continued strength year-over-year.
increasing based on the excellent comment provided by  @jayb : https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1311181

Seems like I needed to update this a while ago.  Book sales have stayed strong much further into the year than expected, so the odds of overcoming 2020 are higher.  Still expecting a drop-off in sales, but at this point it is unlikely to matter.

Industry analyst predicts (remaining) 2021 print book sales will probably slow down but may still exceed 2020 sales by two to ten percent at year's end: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/financial-reporting/article/86935-print-book-sales-could-grow-by-2-this-year-or-by-8.html

Current sales numbers show a decline of only 1.6%. That's not anywhere close to low enough to overcome the huge numbers in the first half (second half sales need to be at least -14% from last year to resolve to no). I'll keep watching, but this seems likely.
people are more inclined for e-readers/digital media

Print book sales declined for the first time for the past week in 2021 compared to the same week in 2020, after a great first half of the year.
https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86886-print-book-sales-fell-last-week-ending-long-winning-streak.html

I am doubling my thought from 20% to 40% from some anecdotal data: A parent I discussed this with claims that this is one of the few activities that kids can participate in that is not a screen. With the rise of zoom classes, eyestrain for chidren as a growing concern and so the fact that 2020's uptick came chiefly from young adult works and children's books indicates no slowing to be expected.

The question can be restated as "will 2021 book sales exceed 751 million in 2021?" With second quarter sales numbers in, the sales are already 387 million. To hit the target, second half sales would need to be 364 million or better. We know that sales won't keep up with last year in the second half (my strong assumption that we won't see another 424 million sales), but it seems unlikely that second half sales will fall below 2019 numbers (380 million). I expect third quarter numbers to be around 160 million. If it's above that, I'll move up. If it's lower, I'll need to reevaluate.
Yes, people have greater access to bookstores and ebooks don't cut it for most people.

Unless i am reading something wrong, I dont know why the crowd is so pessimistic
At this point even a 14% decline over the next 6 months will lead to the target being achieved (link to the calculations below)
https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86863-print-book-sales-soar-in-year-s-first-half.html https://drive.google.com/file/d/1UEYy0btpv3Yqeg1S8BpTvAnCs1KYTq4s/view?usp=sharing

(Excerpt:)  "...that strong performance continued into 2021, with [print sales] units jumping 18.5% in the first six months over the comparable period in 2020." Source: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86863-print-book-sales-soar-in-year-s-first-half.html ..Will see if 2021's robust numbers continue. Up quite a bit so far year-over-year but, as one possible factor influencing numbers, COVID-related issues escalated in the U.S. in the second half of 2020. ..Including reversal of some state re-openings, more contagious strains, no available vaccines, etc.  (https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2020-united-states-coronavirus-outbreak/, https://www.ajmc.com/view/a-timeline-of-covid19-developments-in-2020, https://www.cnbc.com/2020/06/29/more-states-reverse-or-slow-reopening-plans-as-coronavirus-cases-climb.html)

1) preliminary data supports a yes; https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1303686
2) changing my view of people's habits: reading might stick even after lockdowns
3) localized lockdowns are likely to persist as vaccination slows and new variants rise

https://www.anythingresearch.com/2025-Market-Forecast/Books-Printing.htm
It seems that it´s quite possible

It feels like with less restrictions, people will spend more time on outdoors and social activities and less stuck at home and tempted to read. Also, given the high demand for electronic devices in 2020, maybe more people would feel inclined to buy e-versions of books, thus hurting the print book sector.

2020 number was 751 million units. So far 205 million units were already sold in Q1 2021 (as opposed to 158 million copies in Q1 2020). 
https://publishingperspectives.com/2021/04/us-first-quarter-2021-print-book-sales-grew-29-percent-covid19/ Through the week ended June 19, 2021 total print unit sales were up 19.6% over the comparable period a year ago.
https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86738-unit-sales-had-small-gain-last-week.html Even if H2 turns out to be like any other normal year before 2020 (total number being around 690 million units), with the 19.6% surplus already in 2021, the total number of units sold should be higher in 2021.  
https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/85453-a-year-for-the-record-books.html

Updating upwards. Sales are still up.
750.89M sold in 2020 (https://www.statista.com/statistics/422595/print-book-sales-usa/ )
205M sold in Q1 2021 (https://publishingperspectives.com/2021/04/us-first-quarter-2021-print-book-sales-grew-29-percent-covid19/ )
"This marks the highest volume of Q1 print sales since NPD BookScan began tracking sales in 2004"
205M / 750.89M = 0.27 => 27% of 2020 volume sold in 1st quarter.
"Unit sales of print books rose a remarkable 29.2% in the first quarter of 2021 over the same period in 2020"
https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86061-the-print-books-sales-surge-continues.html
All the second quarter news articles I have seen have reported gains over the same week the previous year, so it appears likely that Q2 2021 print book sales will exceed Q2 2020 print book sales.
So, it appears both Q1 and Q2 2021 data may exceed Q1 and Q2 data in 2020.

Per the linked article - using NPD Bookscan numbers - total print book sales are up 19% through 6/27/21 vs. the comparable 2020 period: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86816-print-sales-rose-6-4-at-the-end-of-june.html
Based on the first 6 months, we are op for the year. So it looks increasingly likely. Sales would have to drop now for a decline.

On the one hand, the last 5 years (2016-2020) we have a mean of 704M and Stdev of 30M print book sales per year. We know that Q1 2021 had 205M units sold, so we might extrapolate (if this continues) that this year will have 820M sales. (I couldn't find any info of the seasonality of book sales). This Q1 indicator tells me it is more likely than not that 2021 sales will exceed 2020 sales, but I cannot say by exactly how much. However, this does not take into account the fact that the US is opening up with many states having few or no restrictions, and so this Q1 figure might be an artifact of a world still affected by covid (but this is changing rapidly). Alternatively, if we just use the normal distribution and the figures for the last 5 years, we see that there is a 5.6% percent chance that 2021 will exceed 2020 (again, not using the Q1 '21 figure). I'm going to shift this 5.6 arbitrarily by 5%, and submit a prediction of 10%. (This needs revision).

Q1 2020 was pre-pandemic, so the Q1 to Q1 numbers are very inflated. The rest of the year is competing against the high-water marks from COVID sales. It will be interesting to see the Q2 numbers to get a better gauge of where things are. For now, I'm assuming we will see decreased YoY sales in the latter half of the year and that will bring the annual numbers below last year.
The link found by @jayb ( https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1298106 ) shows that near the midpoint of the year, we're up nearly 20% YoY. What would cause us to be down a greater amount in H2?
Too early to tell but sales seem strong YOY so far in 2021.

following @jayb 's find with print sales being up 19.6% over the same period last year as of June 19 that implies we'd need a healthy drop to not exceed 2020 sales. I'll revise once Q2 numbers are available but that info supports a serious shift in perspective. That said "For bookstores though, how many books are sold each year depends on the success of key months across a twelve-month period, namely August, September, December, and January." (https://www.statista.com/statistics/422595/print-book-sales-usa/) so it's likely far to early to draw any firm conclusions

FWIW: Assuming the following likely means year-to-date unit sales of print books thus far in 2021: "Through the week ended June 19, 2021 total print unit sales were up 19.6% over the comparable period a year ago." Source: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86738-unit-sales-had-small-gain-last-week.html

Going to crowd because I'm not really following it. Makes sense Q1 book sales would beat last years, so maybe looking at YTD numbers is misleading. If we get a dropoff, it should be in the 2nd half of the year. I'm still betting on that, with more people working who have less time to read, but I'm also hedging. I dunno. Employment may be stuck  for a while.

Looking at the percentage increases week over week from last year, things look good.  Looking at the actual numbers, it's going to be close.  Apparently the numbers picked up dramatically last year in the 2nd half of the year.

https://trends.google.nl/trends/explore?date=2020-01-01%202021-06-22&geo=US&q=buy%20book
A five week moving average of this (arguably not ideal) index was in Q1 2021 10% above q1 2020, in the mean time ytd it is 1% lower so i'm gonna go down to market consensus.

2021 print book sales reportedly continue to top 2020 numbers, so far: (Excerpt:) "Last week, total unit sales rose 4.8% over the week ended June 12, 2020, with sales of adult fiction up 23.2% at outlets that report to NPD BookScan. Young adult and juvenile fiction sales were also up in the week." Source: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86683-fiction-leads-another-week-of-sales-gains.html
In the first quarter, they did. What will happen in the next 3?

Some interesting stats released.   Both show high sales in a couple of categories early in year.  So have to revise my earlier pessimistic forecast.
https://www.npd.com/wps/portal/npd/us/news/press-releases/2021/2021-is-shaping-up-to-be-a-very-good-year-for-young-adult-fiction/
https://www.npd.com/wps/portal/npd/us/news/press-releases/2021/adult-fiction-books-posted-highest-q1-sales-since-2013--the-npd-group-says/
Confirmed this is any increase, not an comparison of percentage growth, 0.1% YoY will resolve as a yes. Coupled with data from @jayb, it seems unlikely we will see a decline this year

https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1287514
Increasing my likelihood for yes based on this HT: @jayb

I am fairly confident that this trend will stop this year. Primarily, the use of books has been assisted by the use of textbooks which have been noticeably quiet for this year with the transition to virtual classes. In 2022, it will likely be back on track with this trend.

Hints from both sides, with plenty of time. Though 2020 was maybe an anomalous year, there is evidence pointing to 2021 continuing that trend and a base rate that tells me to tread with caution. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1287532

Need to see comparative 2021 book sales numbers start declining before considering a lower forecast: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86582-print-unit-sales-end-may-with-11-6-increase.html
Yes...people are books like never before..
Book sales now are pretty good, once started by the pandemic these trends will continue for a while so it has momentum.  I am dubious about 2022 though

https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86513-print-unit-sales-rose-2-3-last-week.html Seems like the numbers are still beating last year.  Will be interesting to see what the actual numbers for Q2 are when released.  Revising up slightly.

"Executive summary from NPD BookScan on the first quarter of 2021 sees the volume of sales in print books in the United States growing 29 percent over the same quarter in 2020. That’s representative of 205 million units, over sales of 158 units sold in Q1 2020." Total print book sales in 2020 were 750.89m meaning to beat 2020 totals an average of ~182m per quarter needs to be sold for the rest of 2021. In the 4 years leading up to 2020 sales averaged ~173m / quarter and were growing slightly. If this trend were to continue that would put sales behind 2020. Its possible that the increased sales over the pandemic will have a surplus in the marketplace further reducing sales, but its equally possible that it created more consumers for print books so these factors likely cancel each other out. Numbers will need to be updated quarterly as that seems as frequent as information becomes available but at this point it seems unlikely that 2021 will out sell 2020

From checking past press releases on NPD, previous growth rates were typically around 3%/year, so 2020 was definitely an anomaly: https://www.npd.com/wps/portal/npd/us/news/press-releases/2018/npd-bookscan-recaps-the-year-in-books-2017/. That said, as others have noted, the popularity of books has only increased so far this year: https://publishingperspectives.com/2021/04/us-first-quarter-2021-print-book-sales-grew-29-percent-covid19/. And book sales generally peak during the holidays: https://www.npd.com/wps/portal/npd/us/news/press-releases/2020/one-in-four-books-in-the-us-is-purchased-during-the-holidays/. @DNK89 provides some more numbers: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1275080. It's hard to tell, but I think 2021 looks on track so far.
Need to research more, but I heard some indications on the radio yesterday that print book sales are still up. Revising a bit higher for now.

Print book sales currently ahead of 20202. I think this will regress later in the year but sales remaining higher than expected. https://publishingperspectives.com/2021/04/us-first-quarter-2021-print-book-sales-grew-29-percent-covid19/
Guessing that there will be some retention but ebooks and less time will win out over increased access and increased financial incomes.

I expect that the recent surge in 2020 will not continue with the ending of the pandemic.  I suspect that many people bought books in the pandemic that they never read, so might have a glut, although I also appreciate that people's habits may have changed somewhat and the shock of the pandemic may have made physical books more comforting.  So there is a modest chance of the trend continuing, I think.

also: rise of digital books versus print will dampen the print sale, especially when people can travel again

Pandemic didn't really hit in the US until late Q1 2020 and people were in freakout mode more than reading mode at that point. Maybe people's reading habits will continue post-lockdown...lots of people will have used lockdown to write books and there might be a new J K Rowling among the new writers which could account for a big difference... hmm... probably not too likely on that one... airports reopening mean more sold there... thinking about it though, people won't have as much time to read and maybe not finished all the books they bought last year so maybe a slight decrease...word of mouth on ones they have read might generate some traction... or  a big summer blockbuster though might tip it... or maybe people have been reading more widely so the whole water level rises.... tricky to call at this stage....probably not on balance....

Sales were at their highest because people were stuck at home often.  Soon, they will not be.  Online book sales will improve.  Online libraries will increase in prevalence and stock.  I do not see print books' advantage in the coming year.

https://www.statista.com/statistics/422595/print-book-sales-usa/ I see three factors that will keep print book sales near but below 2020's 750mn copies in 2021:
/750mn copies roughly means three books per reader. This doesn't seem much, considering how many new titles are newly published each year. Large book fairs are still cancelled due to the pandemic, so the diversity of titles will be reduced, smaller publishers, newcomer authors and less well-established writers will struggle, and different time-consuming "cultural/entertainment" occupations such as streaming tv (Netflix, Disney+, movies,...) will dent into people's time devoted for reading. Libraries will increasingly digitize their offer and DRM, digital licenses and ebook lending or shopping are probably the future of book lending, even from the average readers' perspective. Flat fee access to a variety of titles through the likes of amazon kindle will increasingly put pressure on the print book market.
My conclusion is that, while people may spend one more year with above-average hours reading all sorts of creative works, it will hardly translate into more than, say, 725mn copies in printed books. The books you really want to own as a hardcopy are probably those which are either important for educational purpose and value, which you have to revisit frequently, those which - in time of crisis - offer some mental help or solace, and those books which offer an in-depth analysis of the respective crisis or, in turbulent times in general, offer some interesting perspective on or contribute to the large topic of a general debate.
Titles will be preferably sold in hard copy about people who are either idolized (the Obamas' best sellers) or demonized (the Trump re-election campaign and presidency; trying to sell idolization books to Trump supporters is not promising, because they hardly read as much. I think Trump campaigners understood that this would be as successful as selling Trump T-bone steaks to vegetarians...), or working off the justice/law enforcement brutality problem and BLM topic in the public debate by opinion leaders. This has been done in 2020, and 2020 was a pretty exceptional year in this respect (scandals...) which filled a gap.
I don't expect this to repeat in 2021 to the same extent. Many on the long list of publications will end up in the ebook market. /"Supply" of new titles will abate for the same reasons mentioned above. /Print books aren't cheap, and while economic stimulus money was an extra budget for many average readers that enabled them to afford extra print books more easily in 2020 and the first half of 2021, some of the payments will henceforth be bound to a forced return to the labor market (as enforced in some states already), so that a significant chunk of readers will either lack a budget to continue with their reading habits, or lack the time for actual reading. Purchase power doesn't seem to be an issue at the moment, but looking back at historic figures, it was the second and particularly the third year of the "Great Recession" 2009/2010 in which print book sales started their decline for real, probably also due to a more pronounced financial crisis on the individual level, and due to returning inflation in other goods of daily importance. /I also doubt the book market will expand beyond its most recent peak of 780mn copies in 2008 for all the reasons mentioned above (time and financial budget, topics of general interest, digital trends)

The pandemic clearly affected book sales, and it should have a reduced effect this year, as vaccine rollout gradually returns normalcy to the U.S.  Book sales have shown natural growth hovering around 2% per year, which, combined with sales from early this year, might overcome 2020, but I have my doubts.  I initially planned on 5%, but things are pretty uncertain right now, so I'll start with 10.

The growth in the sale of print books in 2020 seems largely due to the pandemic (as stated in articles written about the NPD article linked in the question, source 1). Further, NPD statistics seem to have been led by juvenile fiction, juvenile non-fiction, and adult non-fiction in real terms. However, the growth in adult categories of books was much smaller than juvenile categories in percentage terms. Extrapolating the overall intent of many book purchases seems to be to provide juveniles with something to occupy their time when no longer in school in person and to provide an outlet for adults to better themselves during the pandemic outside of work. If in-person work and school returns across the US in 2021 the overall sales of juvenile books and adult non-fiction will probably not be as robust as in 2020. This does not look likely broadly across the US until the fall. That means three quarters which will probably robust sales of print books at a minimum, which was also the case in 2020 as only three quarters saw strong print book sales in 2020. Therefore, book sales will probably continue to be strong, as was seen in the first quarter of 2021 (source 2).  Source 1: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/85453-a-year-for-the-record-books.html
Source 2: https://publishingperspectives.com/2021/04/us-first-quarter-2021-print-book-sales-grew-29-percent-covid19/

Adding in analysis from @Vincentvd - https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1275393. Q1 Sales of 205M books means that we have 546M remaining units required to hit the 751M. This requires an average of 182M books sold for Q2, Q3, and Q4. While the strong sales number was worth a point, Q1 2021 was very similar to Q4 of 2020 from a lifestyle perspective. The problem is that any misstep in the numbers means we're off-track for this. If Q2 drops exactly to 182M books sold, before things completely started reopening, then that signals a lot of trouble for Q3 and Q4. I'm still doubtful that the school book purchases trend will hold as well because of such strong political pressure to reopen schools. I'm just not seeing the 27% that is the current crowd forecast.

I appreciate this analysis from @higg1508 for giving a solid analysis - https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1275603. I believe a lot of this was due to lockdowns and people running out of things to do at home. There are other reasons cited in the articles are also important to consider - home schooling and kids indoors. The problem that I see is that people bought a ton of cookbooks and self-help books. To me, the cookbooks are going to have been a one-time purchase for most people as they realize that they're not actually using them as often as they'd thought. Self-help might be a more sustainable category, but was probably also used to cope with the crisis and people are looking past this with the prevalence of vaccines. The issue with schooling from home is now its unpopularity. Parents have come to expect the daycare-like quality of the current school system and it would be disastrous if we did not open most school districts for in-person schooling come Fall 2021. Kids will be outdoors and among friends more often = less reading and book purchasing. I'm not sure if we will drop to 2019 levels of books again. We'll probably buoy above this by a bit because the first past of this year was similar to most of 2020. I'm just incredibly skeptical that any of those cited reasons are continuous and going to keep things at where they were last year. Reversion to the mean is a much more likely scenario than some sort of resurrection of book buying.

I anticipate the trend is largely due to lockdowns etc - while less significant (one hopes) in 2021 than 2021, I imagine some of the features of this has/will continue in 2021 - working from home etc (and there must be some chance of a resurgence of covid particularly variants due to irresponsibility as lockdowns are lifted). Lack of commuting may well continue which reduces the comparative demand for audio books/kindle versus real books. Books coming to attention of people during the last year are likely to have attention reinforced as people socialise and discuss in real life, and now can buy them on an impulse buy from real stores. This has a real chance of maintaining relatively high print book sales. Edit - forgot about the election - reduce my estimate to about 25%!
2020 had multiple factors propelling sales, including the Election and forced time at home. Unlikely to be repeated in 2021.

Looking at the categories where sales were good in 2020 and the top sellers I don’t think this year will pass last year.  Why:
1) a lot of juvenile non fiction was sold.  I translate this as a lot of home schooling textbooks and help
2) a lot of the fiction books both adult and juvenile are also likely related to being furloughed, unemployed, or stuck as home during COVID
3) election 2020.  A lot of high profile trump books that were part of the election craziness.  That isn’t going to happen this year. So while I could be completely wrong and there is an underlying trend, take away the above points and I can’t see how 2021 might compete with the 2020 COVID/election demand. Any how many of those 2020 books are still unread too?

2020 started slow  in Q1 and Q2 (1) but was probably saves by Covid and the subsequent lockdowns and other measures in Q3 and 4. The ellection also seems to have had some impact with more people buying political books. (2). Q1 2021 saw the growth from Q4 2020 continue (3)
Whats going to be interesting is how long the Covid measures will stay in place and what will happen with books sales when they are scaled back. 
My expectation is that books sales will see little growth when measure are lifted and people start going out. When this will happen will be a big influence on book sales growth. If life returns to normal at the start of Q3 or earlier books sales will likely not be greater than 2020. If measures are lifted in Q3 there is a change book sales will increase. Given the current vaccination drive 70% vaccination rate should be achieved at the end of august. (4) Also interesting to see is how reading habits have changed. Juvenile books where the top performers of 2020, if a lot of kids can keep the reading habit this could cause a surprise sales lift even when restrictions are lifted.   1:

There was so many catalysts in 2020 for the increase, as mentioned many places, home schooling, online book clubs, BLM and social issues.  Just anecdotal but here the libraries were on and off closed which led to me purchasing more books as well.    But there may yet be catalysts in 2021, some new TV or movie series might spur on massive book sales of a series or even entire genre. If you look at historical sales, print has been growing at a steady 3% since 2012. (https://www.statista.com/statistics/422595/print-book-sales-usa/) My assumption is that lockdowns in the USA, keeping people away from other activities has been the primary driver of increase in sales.  Of the additional sales in 2020, I assume that 10% will carry over into 2021 based on readers picking up the habit for reading print.  Sales in 2020= 751
Sales in 2020 (no covid assuming 3% growth)= 714 37 million additional sales *10%= 3.7 million
Assuming normal 3% year or year growth I would expect 735m sales plus the additional 3.7 million additional sales. = Roughly 741 million in sales in 2021

I noticed the point about unit sales YoY, so I'm setting my probability to slightly above the consensus and revisiting in a week. My original view was we might be above 2019 but less than last year, but it could end up being a close finish given the headstart for 2021.  One curveball is new variants causing lockdowns, but vaccine dev for variants is looking good, and the US is doing well with vaccine access for people who want it. But I don't believe there is pent up demand for books, since household savings are already high we've likely been maxing out discretionary book consumption. On the point about lumber prices: The final cost of a book is just a fraction of the raw materials. I don't think it would matter too much since a lot of books are substitutes and come with varying prices. The YoY increase has occurred with this factor already in play.
Good point by @wlmsears. Maybe people have formed new habits? Adjusting my prediction.

I can't see it happening. With the pandemic happening, the resulting price of lumber has exploded. The cost of procuring materials for books has to be related to the supply of the wood somehow... not sure yet, but to me if wood is more expensive, that cost is going to be passed on to the consumer. So, even if there are more produced, costs could prove prohibitive in a relative sense of book purchasing. Want to look more in to the correlation as related to physical book production...  https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/lumber-prices-hit-record-highs-soaring-past-year-2021-4-1030299977

I would expect regression to the mean after a best-in-a-decade result quite likely driven by COVID and likely to recede as restrictions are relaxed. However, "Unit sales of all print books were up 26% through May 1 compared to the same period in 2020."
(Source: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86268-print-units-rose-12-4-last-week.html) IDK how often these estimates are revised, but I'll be checking roughly monthly to update my prediction.

I doubt it. Sales went way up because of the pandemic. Now, people want to go ***out***. Many restrictions are likely to be lifted once everyone who wants a vaccine has had one (e.g., as in New York), and I don't think books are going to be on quite as many people's minds.

As pointed out by others here: "Unit sales of all print books were up 26% through May 1 compared to the same period in 2020." 
(Source: https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86268-print-units-rose-12-4-last-week.html) However, comparative 2020 sales were reportedly only beginning to recover/increase around late April of that year. (https://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/bookselling/article/86234-print-unit-sales-surge-in-late-april.html)  We'll see if 2021 can continue to exceed 2020's highest-in-a-decade surge, going forward.  E.g.: Fewer cookbooks required plus fewer kids "stuck at home" in '21? (https://publishingperspectives.com/2021/01/npd-2020-was-the-us-markets-bestselling-year-for-print-in-a-decade-covid19/)
First quarter sales were up a lot this year, which provides a base.
Last year appears to have been an anomaly, but perhaps the habit has been formed and the new trend will continue.
